Expanse has hundreds of career opportunity with thousands of cross-overs. There are no restrictions besides the genre. (Cleric & Shek-Pvar obviously don’t fit in.) The same is true for parent occupation. Instead of occupations determining skill knowledge, use 40 OPs on the skill list below and create a biography that fits the selection. For further eludication, see the “World” description in the section on Occupations.
This section actually describes the world in broad terms, to give a feeling of careers that are possible. Occupations as such do not exist, only choices on skills that can be developed.

Humans still live on well-populated Earth (5.000.000.000) but Earth is striken with plagues, environmental hazards and petty wars. Mars has been colonized and has claimed independence since 30 years ago. Originally a generic scientific undertaking, its population (500.000.000) focuses on terraforming. Mars does not have the gravity to bind a breatheable atmossphere. Scattered across the asteroid belt and moons of the outer planets, the human belters (50.000.000) live. Ganymede is the largest hub with about 5.000.000 residents.

The solar system is mainly according to current state of physics. The speed of light is a hard boundary for travel and space is extremely vast. That being said, certain creative extensions are made. Mainly space propulsion is relative easy to come by, the so-called”Epstein-Drive” or sideric drive. But there are no flashy laser weapons or artificial gravity. Getting material and people of the Earth (and to a lesser degree Mars) is still a very expensive thing.

Society on the outer moons and the belt is similar to the wild west, but on a higher technologic level. Information takes hours to travel from one planet to the next and ships may take days. Mars is a centralistic, technocracy and Earth the usual, squabbling league of nations. However, the UN has achieved an authority level as the EU government has in the year 2000, probably a bit more. In particular it has troops, nominally only to use them in Space.

Big cooperations spanning the planets dominate commerce. The interdependencies are hard to gauge and change often, as companies divide into smaller units to avoid taxes, press smaller countries into servive, try to avoid bad press and so on. The last “monopoly bust” was just 10 years ago, when a Belt-mining company was split into three. Humans on earth have a life-expectancy of 100 years, on Mars 75 and belters of 50.
All new weapons introduced are firearms. In fact there are myriads of options to customize a weapon.
Name: Whole classes are listed with a parameter range in which to choose from.

I: Impact is equivalent to a calibre and can be treated as interchangeable between different manufacturers. Converting bullets from one class to another and lowering the impact rating requires a gunsmith. Impact has the point aspect only. At higher levels the distinction between different aspects becomes moot.
RC: is the range class, explained in a later table.

WT: Weight of the unloaded handgun (or with a single bullet in the chamber) is calculated with the given formula and given in grams. The weight of a single bullet Impact x 20 grams and called IW (Impact Weight).
Price: An abstract unit currently, for comparison only equate this to US Dollars or Euros in the year 2000. The cost for Ammunition is its Impact rating per bullet in units.
Clip: show the range of ammo batches available. They only come in multiiples shown in paranthesis. The weight of a clip is the number of rounds it contains multiplied by the bullets' weight.

ROF: The rate of fire is bullets fired per second, which all must be aimed. The rate of fire can be arbitrarily adjusted in the given range, autoburst and other contemporary restrictions no longer apply.
The ML for any offense is decreased by two (2) for each bullet fired above the first. That is, a character firing 3 bullets per second subtracts 4 from ML for all attack rolls.

Note that a Small gun can be fired with one hand and secondary hand penalty applies. A Medium gun can be fired with one hand at -5 penalty and twice the multiple target penalty and RC reduced by one. A Heavy gun cannot be fired with one hand. A heavy gun needs stationary bracing, if this is not available, a -5 penalty and twice the multiple target penalty apply and RC reduced to three (3). A superheavy weapon needs a stationary mount and if only bracing is available, the -5 penalty and twice the multiple target penalty apply. RC is reduced to (3). Light artillery cannot be fired without stationary mount. If it is discharged none-the-less, only the first shot is at -5 with RC2, while everything else are “wild” results at best.
All weapons fall into the range classes below. Sometimes weapons have properties of lower range classes, when inferior conditions exist, usually protective measures against recoil.
All Medium Guns provide a Defense ML modifier of Club, all Small Guns as as a Knife. Heavy Guns and beyond usually provide cover and cannot be used as Defensive weapon.

If desired, roll a “self-attack” by the used weapon to determine if a Jam or other malfunction occurs. Any Damage taken precludes further operation of the weapon until gunsmithing is applied. “Minor” damage can be repaired in the field with general purpose tools.

With the advent of weapons with high penetration, cover becomes more important and the thicker, the better. The table shows the protective values for material cover per centimetre thickness. Other materials can be modelled to scale their protective value with density.
Specialised ammunition may be used instead of the standard ammunition. A Gunsmith can provide these. Some Examples:
Advanced Energy Transfer: AET ammunition is available for small and medium guns only. Add +5 to the wound points; this will aggrevate the wound level as well. Cost is 30 times normal.

Armour Piercing: AP ammunition are designed to maximise penetration through hard cover. Available for small through heavy guns. Add +5 to Strike Impact when comparing against armour, but reduce the wound level by 10 (effectively by 5). Cost is 3 times normal.

Glaser: Frangible ammunition that comprises numerous tiny pellets inside a thin metal jacket. The drawback of this round is that it has poor penetration. Available for Small Guns only. Reduce Strike Impact by five (5) before comparing against armour, but add twenty (20) (effectively 15) to wound level. Cost is 15 times normal.
Rubber: These bullets cause Blunt Trauma instead of puncture and any Wound level caused (after armour reduction) is further reduced by five (5).

When a clip is out of ammunition, it takes a Grope action to load another cartridge for Small guns, Subtract 20 for Medium Guns and 40 for Heavy Guns, 100 for Superheavy Weapons, and at least 200 for artillery. This all assumes that the next cartridge or cask is close by, i.e. within 5 ft.

For stationary targets special equipment exists to improve the aiming bonus, by spending 1 second per bonus point, limited by the eyesight skill value. Note that military grade equipment also includes guided missiles, this is not meant here.

When firing at a human, any Wound exceeding 4 x Size can be considered passing through to the next target. This value is after deducting armour values, but do not calculate those twice, i.e. for exiting armour on the other side.
New armor is available in some locations. Prices may vary wildly as with weapons. Weight is in kilograms.

All explosions inflict Impact with different aspects. The indicated value is inflicted at the center and reduced by 1 for each foot of distance. Cover applies and Penetrating hits. On the other hand, all exposed Main Locations are affected likewise, making explosives very dangerous. Special care needs to be taken when damaging walls, in underwater environments and other circumstances that may increase or decrease effects. In general, explosions continue around corners with a penalty of one (1) for each 10° off course from center. Fragments (P aspect) do not go around corners. Otherwise, Explosives are treated as missiles with a duration of 1 second. Fuses for throwing are standard and can be set to arbitrary values but default to 4 seconds. Note that thrown objects are in the air for the time mentioned in the table. Straight throws are possible up to 10 meters in 1s on Earth (1g) but exact or optimal values can only be calculated with mathematics skill or similar. Otherwise randomize. Grenade launchers boost throwing strength by 20 points

Some Equipment may be limited and its sale or existence may be tracked. Some carry sensors that allow officials to jam operations. These items may be cheaper or not, restrictions are often not advertised.

Scope: A scope increases EYE by 5 to 20. The low-end variant costs 50, while the high-end is 400. Each weighs 200g. Note that special medium guns also exist as variants that have more or less infinitely extended range penalties for RC3. They cost 10 times as much as the normal version. These are sniper versions and they invariably require scopes.

Laser: When mounted these grant +10 to any Small, Medium, or Heavy Gun. The use is reduced with weather and the like. Modify the bonus by -1 for each 10% decrease in visibility. A typical laser sight weighs just 100g, costs 350 and uses a standard, small battery.

Night Vision: These Goggles can be mounted to a gun or used without one. They decrease any EYE penalty due to low light by up to 20. Imaging itself however causes a -5 penalty. A typical night vision google weighs just 100g, costs 350 and uses a standard, small battery.

Sound Suppressor: These are mounted to the muzzle and reduce sounds by 5 points. A typical sound suppressor weighs just 100g and costs 350. Special, powered silencers exist that reduce shot gun noise by 10 points but they cost 1000.

Thermal Imagers: These Goggles are used without weapon. They increase tracking rolls by 10 and work as half-efficient Night Vision in the Dark. They also allow detection behind thin covering. A typical thermal scanner weighs just 1kg, costs 1000 and uses a standard, medium battery.
First Aid Kit: Cost 50, 1 kg. Supplies 2 First Aid operations, which is a Row-5-Addition of 10 to Physician. Includes instructions, which itself provides a Row-5-Addition to Physician of 5.
Field Surgery Kit: Cost 150, 1 kg. Allows Surgery treatment with a Row-5-Addition of 5 to Physician.

Medicine is greatly improved compared to Hârn. With the proper tools and medicine, Physician skills may easily be improved by almost arbitrary bonuses. The cost for the bonus is listed in the table and applied through Row-5 Addition. There are more ways of dealing with wounds that are only short of regrowing a limb. Any destruction level wound remains untreatable, but other than that. The costs involve dedicated hand-held equipment, an Emergency Care Unit, to specifically created operation robots and regrow facilities. Thus Juryn, the famed doctor with a skill of 25, can treat a wound in his field of expertise with 25+510 width readily available medication and procedures. That will cost 1000 in materials and does not include the amount that Jurin himself puts on the bill for his patient. But the arm that was torn off by a robot in the blink of an eye, including bad lesions and other nerve-wrecking damage with a wound level of 20, will probably heal nicely.

Triggered: Your own Initiative can be increased by +10, if an action is postponed by one or more seconds. Not all actions can be postponed and in some cases it does not make sense, GM discretion applies. The benefit is that a positive result can be achieved and threats enhanced. Any action besides waiting resets the bonus.

Pinning: To prevent an enemy from moving or firing back, preemptive firing is an option. Repetitive firing each second increases your own Initiative by +20. The bonus applies only after a first shot without bonus and changing the target resets the condition. Only weapons firing at least once per second can use this.
This is a list of Spaceships, whose technical specifications are available. Military secrets still aply and some rare technology may improve ships dramatically in certain areas.
Tonage is usually weight in tons and linear to the cubic meters of enclosed space. Every cubic meter of steel plated ship weight 500kg. When designing Tonnage consider space port sizes.

Structure is the amount of g the ship can sustain without breaking apart. Lift-off is usually at 1 g plus the stellar body’s gravity one lifts off from. As the tomage inceases, structural stability decreases.
Guns shows the typical armourment. Number of guns times the typical damage they cause. Armour is the reduction of damage from a hit as always.
Planetary shuttles are used to ferry passengers and goods from and to planets with more than marginal gravity. In the solar system these are only Mars and Earth.
Space shuttles are the ferries between moons and asteroids, which do not need to fly through gravitational fields.
Freighters are civilian ships between inner and outer planets and their moons, they are the most varied ships in the solar system. Some include smaller ferry boats, but this is rare.
Gunboats are fast ships but not armned too heavily. Warships are the most heavily armed and costly of all ships. Carriers transport their own tonage in gunboats.

Spaceships are built in compartments of approximately 10T each. Thus any hull breach will immediately result in bulkheads to shut the affected areas down. Depending on the affected area, they may or may not continue to be functional. Ships are organized in such a way that most such cells can continue to operate the remaining functional cells. Some jamming weapons may prevent that. The fusion reactor is 10T minimum for planetary vessels and 0.05T/(1g*1T) otherwise. Thus the size scales with maximum thrust and tonage. If this receives a substantial hit, an explosion consuming 1km radius per ton is likely to occur.

The number given in the price category are interplanetary credits. Ships cost 4000 per ton. Heavy artillery mounted to space stations cost 200 times their impact rating. For any construction that needs to be able to withstand accelaration, use the price multiplier from the table.

The costs are “end-consumer” prices and selling equipment is rarely possible and usually at less than half price, particularly for non-pristine equipment. Additionally, all economic rules apply, such as demand and supply rules, cornering markets, trade tariffs, etc. Assume that the prices are valid at Earth space-ports under free market conditions. Buying in the belt or on Mars may see stiff increases or occasional drops, when contraband or plunder is being sold. Use Street-wise as skill (among others) to trade profitably.

Fuel and general maintenance of a space ship is generally 1/100 of its build cost per day. Cost when not travelling are assumed equivalent to travel costs, as port fees need to be payed and maintenance is actually done. Destruction, such as that inflicted diuring space combat, can often not be repaired and instead requires rebuilding.

On Earth there are no space ports that allow more than 1 kT to start. Most will only allow 100 T. (1T = 1000 kg.) Mars has one port for 1 kT and 2 for 300 T. Spaceports on moons and spacedocks are usually arbitrary size, Luna is the prime example, with a gravity of 1/6. There are three space ports in orbit around Earth. They provide ferry services to the surface. There is no spaceport around Mars.

Some spaceport make a fuss about actual tonagr for freighters landing and lifting off and armour plating increasing weight and such. Pilots trying to test the limits of a space port may find themselves grounded or worse: they need to jettison contents or parts from their ship. Docking and undocking fees follow a quadratic law with respect to tonage, so the larger freighters tend to use shuttles and rather lose time than too much money on goods in transfer. This makes most space ports busy places.

Nuclear, Chemical and Biological Weapons are banned and strictly controlled by all involved parties able to produce them. They are known to exist in forms that eradicate a non-separated population within weeks, or eradicate a cubic voulume of 1 cubic kilometer with “grievous” consequences in the surrounding volume. None of these weapons produce relevant damage in empty space. The explosion radius of a nuclear weapon is 1/10th of that in an atmossphere. Effects on Mars have not been studied.

The most devastating weapon in space combat that is deemed acceptable by interplanetary law are autonomous, guided missiles. They are guided by an AI and a heat-sensor that locks onto a heat signature and accelerates at 20g. This makes them extremely hard to deflect (but scattering fine debries at smaller velocities have been known to work, when the missile has sufficient speed. Most ships automatically close down all bulkheads when such a weapon comes within sensor range immediately and will maneuver its body between the missile and the reactor(s). Closing on impact would be too slow. Evasion is useless. Impact is weight in kg times the number of seconds this weapon spends in flight. On a ship they take space appropriate for their weight. They can have almost any form but are mostly cubes. They are destroyed upon impact. Most will simply cut through any ship like butter. In rare cases, the missile might impact another ship, but rarely do they fly in such close proximity. Missile may be triggered to explode instead of penetration. In this case they trigger when they have given off a preset percentage of their penetration damage and explode for at most 10% of their weight in the cell they land in.

Example: A missile of 270kg flies through space for 20 seconds before it hits the Fortune, a 300T warship. It generates 4000 points of impact damage and would rip through 40 cells with the Fortune’s armour plating of 100 points. The Fortune only has 30 cells, but they are clustered 3x3x3+3 in such a way that only 4 cells are penetrated. The weapon material can be thought of as having a density of 10kg/dm3, thus the hole through the ship would be 30cm x 30cm. Fortunately, this wasn’t the exploding type. Assuming it was, one cell would have seen an explosion for 27kg / 20g = 1350 points. Note that cells reduce impact inbound and outbound. The explosion is also directed in all directions, so this means 200 points are reduced in 6 directions before breaching neighboring cells. On average, all 6 neighboring cells (assuming there are any) would take 25 points of damage. Any living being would be in serious trouble and computers or other delicate machinery is likely ruined.
Random damage in Space through debris depends on speed and time. Since speed depends on acceleration mostly, the following table assumes that you accelerate or decelerate at the constant rate.

At different acceleration rates, the time needed to receive the appropriate damage is divided accordingly. E.g. at 3g, it only takes 1 month at that speed to receive a strike of 100 impact. Alternatively, the modifier can be used. This roll can be made routine by only considering one day at a time and roll an n5 every day (at 1g). Debris that can cause damage to space stations on moons can be ignored. Since all debris and all “stationary” moons move on a regular course, collisions are automatically detected and usually taken care of ahead of time. Weapons or intentional cloaking of such collisions are another matter. See guided missiles.
